conclusion: To solve the problem, analyze waveforms in Figures 1 and 2, determine wave direction, and calculate wave speed using amplitude and time information.
Figure 1 depicts a wave at time t = 2 seconds with amplitude A = 10 cm. Figure 2 shows a particle at position x = 2 meters. Both figures illustrate a transverse harmonic wave.
In Figure 1, the wave is moving from left to right, suggesting propagation along the positive x-axis.
Wave speed v can be calculated using the formula v = λ/T, where λ is the wavelength and T is the period.
The period T is the time taken for one complete cycle, which is 4 seconds in Figure 1.
The wavelength λ can be found from the distance between two consecutive peaks or troughs, which is 2 meters in Figure 1.
Substitute values into the speed formula: v = 2 m / 4 s = 0.5 m/s.
The wave speed is consistent with the direction of wave propagation, confirming correct interpretation of wave direction and speed.
The direction of wave propagation is along the positive x-axis. The wave speed is 0.5 m/s.
